channel.title: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!
channel.description:
Ok,
So i need when playerX with id 1 has attacked playerY with id 2 and then in process it needs to check if playerY is still drunk or something else
so i need something like this in attack case: test == plz.playerId then in process it needs to check if the attacked player is drunk if(timer == 0 && test.stilldrunk) { blalbla }
so if the playerX attacks the playerY. Then playerX stops attacking and then it needs to check if playerY is drunken
it gives me errors because it cannot be : "int cannot be dereferenced"
is there a way to fix it?
i knew this already: From what it looks, you have 'test' declared as an int (primitive type) and you can't dereference it with the . so that would be the problem
but idk how to fix it, that's the problem =( to what i need to change "test" theN?
thanks in advance jonas

item.title: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!
item.dc:creator: @jonaske jonaske
item.description:
@jonaske wrote:

I know that already…
BUT I NEED A FIX OR HOW CAN I DO IT SO IT DOESN’T GIVE ME AN ERROR??
PLEASE I BEG YOU!!![br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 10, 2008, 03:28:02 AM[/size][hr]please - bump

Read full topic
item.source: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!

item.title: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Basically you’re saying int = int.int.
You can’t reference an int from an int.

Read full topic
item.source: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!

item.title: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!

item.description:

but i need to check if he is “stilldrunk”, i don’t need a guy that’s called stilldrunk??
could you say what i do wrong? or a fix plz i beg you

item.title: Int cannot be dereferenced - only advanced coders! - need fix!
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Int dosen’t have a member called “stilldrunk”, for a start.

Ok,

So i need when playerX with id 1 has attacked playerY with id 2
and then in process it needs to check if playerY is still drunk or something else

so i need something like this
in attack case: test == plz.playerId
then in process it needs to check if the attacked player is drunk
if(timer == 0 && test.stilldrunk) {
blalbla
}

so if the playerX attacks the playerY.
Then playerX stops attacking and then it needs to check if playerY is drunken

i knew this already:
From what it looks, you have ‘test’ declared as an int (primitive type) and you can’t dereference it with the . so that would be the problem
